column3: When impeded in their progress, these people suddenly ceased muttering, but re doubled their gesticulations, and awaited, with an absent and overdone smile upon the lips, the course of the persons impeding them.

column2: Their habiliments belonged to that order which is pointedly termed the decent.

column2: Theirs was the affectation of respectability;--if indeed there be an affectation so honorable.

column2: They seem to prey upon the public in two battalions--that of the dandies and that of the military men.

column2: Of the first grade the leading features are long locks and smiles; of the second frogged coats and frowns.

column2: Descending in the scale of what is termed gentility, I found darker and deeper themes for speculation.
column3: Descending in the scale of what is termed gentility, I found darker and deeper themes for speculation.

column2: I saw Jew pedlars, with hawk eyes flashing from countenances whose every other feature wore only an expression of abject humility; sturdy professional street beggars scowling upon mendicants of a better stamp, whom despair alone had driven forth into the night for charity; feeble and ghastly invalids, upon whom death had placed a sure hand, and who sidled and tottered through the mob, looking every one beseechingly in the face, as if in search of some chance consolation, some lost hope; modest young girls returning from long and late labor to a cheerless home, and shrinking more tearfully than indignantly from the glances of ruffians, whose direct contact, even, could not be avoided; women of the town of all kinds and of all ages--the unequivocal beauty in the prime of her womanhood, putting one in mind of the statue in Lucian, with the surface of Parian marble, and the interior filled with filth--the loathsome and utterly lost leper in rags--the wrinkled, bejewelled and paint-begrimed beldame, making a last effort at youth--the mere child of immature form, yet, from long association, an adept in the dreadful coquetries of her trade, and burning with a rabid ambition to be ranked the equal of her elders in vice; drunkards innumerable and indescribable--some in shreds and patches, reeling, inarticulate, with bruised visage and lack-lustre eyes--some in whole although filthy garments, with a slightly unsteady swagger, thick sensual lips, and hearty-looking rubicund faces--others clothed in materials which had once been good, and which even now were scrupulously well brushed--men who walked with a more than naturally firm and springy step, but whose countenances were fearfully pale, whose eyes hideously wild and red, and who clutched with quivering fingers, as they strode through the crowd, at every object which came within their reach; beside these, pie-men, porters, coal--heavers, sweeps; organ-grinders, monkey-exhibiters and ballad mongers, those who vended with those who sang; ragged artizans and exhausted laborers of every description, and all full of a noisy and inordinate vivacity which jarred discordantly upon the ear, and gave an aching sensation to the eye.
column3: I saw Jew pedlars, with hawk eyes flashing from countenances whose every other feature wore only an expression of abject humility; sturdy professional street beggars scowling upon mendicants of a better stamp, whom despair alone had driven forth into the night for charity; drunkards innumerable and indescribable-some in shreds and patches, reeling, inarticulate, with bruised visage and lack lustre eyes-some in whole although filthy garments, with a slightly unsteady swagger, thick sensual lips, and hearty looking rubicund faces-others clothed in materials which had once been good, and which even now were scrupulously well brushed-men who walked with a more than naturally firm and springy step, but whose countenances were fearfully pale, whose eyes hideously wild and red, and who clutched with quivering fingers, as they strode through the crowd, at every object which came within their reach; beside these, pie men, porters, coal-heavers, sweeps; organ grinders, monkey exhibiters and ballad mongers, those who vended with those who sang; ragged artizans and exhausted laborers of every description, and all full of a noisy and inordinate vivacity which jarred discordantly upon the ear, and gave an aching sensation to the eye.

column2: As the night deepened, so deepened to me the interest of the scene; for not only did the general character of the crowd materially alter (its gentler features retiring in the gradual withdrawal of the more orderly portion of the people, and its harsher ones coming out into bolder relief, as the late hour brought forth every species of infamy from its den,) but the rays of the gas-lamps, feeble at first in their struggle with the dying day, had now at length gained ascendancy, and threw over every thing a fitful and garish lustre.
column3: As the night deepened, so deepened to me the interest of the scene; for not only did the general character of the crowd materially alter (its gentler features retiring in the gradual withdrawal of the more orderly portion of the people, and its harsher ones coming out into bolder relief, as the late hour brought forth every species of infamy from its den,) but the rays of the gas lamps, feeble at first in their struggle with the dying day, had now at length gained ascendancy, and threw over every thing a fitful and garish lustre.

column2: All was dark yet splendid--as that ebony to which has been likened the style of Tertullian.

column2: The wild effects of the light enchained me to an examination of individual faces; and although the rapidity with which the world of light flitted before the window, prevented me from casting more than a glance upon each visage, still it seemed that, in my then peculiar mental state, I could frequently read, even in that brief interval of a glance, the history of long years.

column2: With my brow to the glass, I was thus occupied in scrutinizing the mob, when suddenly there came into view a countenance (that of a decrepid old man, some sixty-five or seventy years of age,)--a countenance which at once arrested and absorbed my whole attention, on account of the absolute idiosyncrasy of its expression.

column2: As I endeavored, during the brief minute of my original survey, to form some analysis of the meaning conveyed, there arose confusedly and paradoxically within my mind, the ideas of vast mental power, of caution, of penuriousness, of avarice, of coolness, of malice, of blood thirstiness, of triumph, of merriment, of excessive terror, of intense--of supreme despair.

column2: Hurriedly putting on an overcoat, and seizing my hat and cane, I made my way into the street, and pushed through the crowd in the direction which I had seen him take; for he had already disappeared. column2: He was short in stature, very thin, and apparently very feeble.

column3: His clothes, generally, were filthy and ragged; but as he came, now and then, within the strong glare of a lamp, I perceived that his linen, although dirty, was of beautiful texture; and my vision deceived me, or, through a rent in a closely buttoned and evidently second handed roquelaire which enveloped him, I caught a glimpse both of a diamond and of a dagger.

column3: These observations heightened my curiosity, and I resolved to follow the stranger whithersoever he should go.

column2: Tying a handkerchief about my mouth, I kept on.

column3: For half an hour the old man held his way with difficulty along the great thoroughfare; and I here walked close at his elbow through fear of losing sight of him.

column2: Never once turning his head to look back, he did not observe me.
column3: Never once turning his head to look back, he did not observe me.

column2: By and bye he passed into a cross street, which, although densely filled with people, was not quite so much thronged as the main one he had quitted.
column3: By and bye he passed into a cross street, which, although densely filled with people, was not quite so much thronged as the main one he had quitted.

column2: Here a change in his demeanor became evident.

column2: He walked more slowly and with less object than before--more hesitatingly.
column3: He walked more slowly and with less object than before-more hesitatingly.

column2: He crossed and re-crossed the way repeatedly without apparent aim; and the press was still so thick that, at every such movement, I was obliged to follow him closely. The street was a narrow and long one, and his course lay within it for nearly an hour, during which the passengers had gradually diminished to about that number which is ordinarily seen at noon in Broadway near the Park--so vast a difference is there between a London populace and that of the most frequented American city.
column3: He crossed and re crossed the way repeatedly without apparent aim; and the press was still so thick that, at every such movement, I was obliged to follow him closely. column2: A second turn brought us into a square, brilliantly lighted, and overflowing with life.
column3: A second turn brought us into a square, brilliantly lighted, and overflowing with life.

column2: The old manner of the stranger re-appeared.

column2: His chin fell upon his breast, while his eyes rolled wildly from under his knit brows, in every direction, upon those who hemmed him in.

column2: He urged his way steadily and perseveringly.

column3: I was surprised, however, to find, upon his having made the circuit of the square, that he turned and retraced his steps.

column2: In this exercise he spent another hour, at the end of which we met with far less interruption from passengers than at first.
column3: In this exercise he spent another hour, at the end of which we met with far less interruption from passengers than at first.

column2: The rain fell fast; the air grew cool; and the people were retiring to their homes.
column3: The rain fell fast; the air grew cool; and the people were retiring to their homes.

column2: With a gesture of impatience, the wanderer passed into a bye-street comparatively deserted.
column3: With a gesture of impatience, the wanderer passed into a bye street comparatively deserted.

column2: Down this, some quarter of a mile long, he rushed with an activity I could not have dreamed of seeing in one so aged, and which put me to much trouble in pursuit.
column3: Down this, some quarter of a mile long, he rushed with an activity I could not have dreamed of seeing in one so aged, and which put me to much trouble in pursuit.

column2: A few minutes brought us to a large and busy bazaar, with the localities of which the stranger appeared well acquainted, and where his original demeanor again became apparent, as he forced his way to and fro, without aim, among the host of buyers and sellers.
column3: A few minutes brought us to a large and busy bazaar, with the localities of which the stranger appeared well acquainted, and where his original demeanor again became apparent, as he forced his way to and fro, without aim, among the host of buyers and sellers.

column2: During the hour and a half, or thereabouts, which we passed in this place, it required much caution on my part to keep him within reach without attracting his observation.
column3: During the hour and a half, or thereabouts, which we passed in this place, it required much caution on my part to keep him within reach without attracting his observation.

column2: Luckily I wore a pair of caoutchouc over-shoes, and could move about in perfect silence.
column3: Luckily I wore a pair of caoutchouc over shoes, and could move about in perfect silence.

column2: At no moment did he see that I watched him.
column3: At no moment did he see that I watched him.

column2: He entered shop after shop, priced nothing, spoke no word, and looked at all objects with a wild and vacant stare. I was now utterly amazed at his behavior, and firmly resolved that we should not part until I had satisfied myself in some measure respecting him.
column3: He entered shop after shop, priced nothing, spoke no word, and looked at all objects with a wild and vacant stare. I was now utterly amazed at his behavior, and firmly resolved that we should not part until I had satisfied myself in some measure respecting him.

column2: A loud-toned clock struck eleven, and the company were fast deserting the bazaar.
column3: A loud toned clock struck eleven, and the company were fast deserting the bazaar.

column2: A shop-keeper, in putting up a shutter, jostled the old man, and at the instant I saw a strong shudder come over his frame.
column3: A shop keeper, in putting up a shutter, jostled the old man, and at the instant I saw a strong shudder come over his frame.

column2: He hurried into the street, looked anxiously around him for an instant, and then ran with incredible swiftness through many crooked and people-less lanes, until we emerged once more upon the great thoroughfare whence we had started--the street of the D---- Hotel.
column3: He hurried into the street, looked anxiously around him for an instant, and then ran with incredible swiftness through many crooked and people less lanes, until we emerged once more upon the great thoroughfare whence we had started-the street of the D---- Hotel.

column2: It no longer wore, however, the same aspect.
column3: It no longer wore, however, the same aspect.

column2: It was still brilliant with gas; but the rain fell fiercely, and there were few persons to be seen.
column3: It was still brilliant with gas; but the rain fell fiercely, and there were few persons to be seen.

column2: The stranger grew pale. He walked moodily some paces up the once populous avenue, then, with a heavy sigh, turned in the direction of the river, and, plunging through a great variety of devious ways, came out, at length, in view of one of the principal theatres.
column3: The stranger grew pale. He walked moodily some paces up the once populous avenue, then, with a heavy sigh, turned in the direction of the river, and, plunging through a great variety of devious ways, came out, at length, in view of one of the principal theatres.

column2: It was about being closed, and the audience were thronging from the doors.
column3: It was about being closed, and the audience were thronging from the doors.

column2: I saw the old man gasp as if for breath while he threw himself amid the crowd; but I thought that the intense agony of his countenance had, in some measure, abated.
column3: I saw the old man gasp as if for breath while he threw himself amid the crowd; but I thought that the intense agony of his countenance had, in some measure, abated.

column2: His head again fell upon his breast; he appeared as I had seen him at first.
column3: His head again fell upon his breast; he appeared as I had seen him at first.

column2: I observed that he now took the course in which had gone the greater number of the audience--but, upon the whole, I was at a loss to comprehend the waywardness of his actions.
column3: I observed that he now took the course in which had gone the greater number of the audience-but, upon the whole, I was at a loss to comprehend the waywardness of his actions.

column2: As he proceeded, the company grew more scattered, and his old uneasiness and vacillation were resumed.
column3: As he proceeded, the company grew more scattered, and his old uneasiness and vacillation were resumed.

column2: For some time he followed closely a party of some ten or twelve roisterers; but from this number one by one dropped off, until three only remained together, in a narrow and gloomy lane little frequented.
column3: For some time he followed closely a party of some ten or twelve roisterers; but from this number one by one dropped off, until three only remained together, in a narrow and gloomy lane little frequented.

column2: The stranger paused, and, for a moment, seemed lost in thought; then, with every mark of agitation, pursued rapidly a route which brought us to the verge of the city, amid regions very different from those we had hitherto traversed.
column3: The stranger paused, and, for a moment, seemed lost in thought; then, with every mark of agitation, pursued rapidly a route which brought us to the verge of the city, amid regions very different from those we had hitherto traversed.

column2: It was the most noisome quarter of London, where every thing wore the worst impress of the most deplorable poverty, and of the most desperate crime.
column3: It was the most noisome quarter of London, where every thing wore the worst impress of the most deplorable poverty, and of the most desperate crime.

column2: By the dim light of an accidental lamp, tall, antique, worm-eaten, wooden tenements were seen tottering to their fall, in directions so many and capricious that scarce the semblance of a passage was discernible between them. The paving-stones lay at random, displaced from their beds by the rankly-growing grass.
column3: By the dim light of an accidental lamp, tall, antique, worm eaten, wooden tenements were seen tottering to their fall, in directions so many and capricious that scarce the semblance of a passage was discernible between them. The paving stones lay at random, displaced from their beds by the rankly growing grass.

column2: Horrible filth festered in the dammed-up gutters. The whole atmosphere teemed with desolation.
column3: Horrible filth festered in the dammed up gutters. The whole atmosphere teemed with desolation.

column2: Yet, as we proceeded, the sounds of human life revived by sure degrees, and at length large bands of the most abandoned of a London populace were seen reeling to and fro. The spirits of the old man again flickered up, as a lamp which is near its death hour.
column3: Yet, as we proceeded, the sounds of human life revived by sure degrees, and at length large bands of the most abandoned of a London populace were seen reeling to and fro. The spirits of the old man again flickered up, as a lamp which is near its death hour.

column2: Once more he strode onward with elastic tread.
column3: Once more he strode onward with elastic tread.

column2: Suddenly a corner was turned, a blaze of light burst upon our sight, and we stood before one of the huge suburban temples of Intemperance--one of the palaces of the fiend, Gin.
column3: Suddenly a corner was turned, a blaze of light burst upon our sight, and we stood before one of the huge suburban temples of Intemperance-one of the palaces of the fiend, Gin.

column2: It was now nearly day-break; but a number of wretched inebriates still pressed in and out of the flaunting entrance.
column3: It was now nearly day break; but a number of wretched inebriates still pressed in and out of the flaunting entrance.

column2: With a half shriek of joy the old man forced a passage within, resumed at once his original bearing, and stalked backward and forward, without apparent object, among the throng.
column3: With a half shriek of joy the old man forced a passage within, resumed at once his original bearing, and stalked backward and forward, without apparent object, among the throng.

column2: He had not been thus long occupied, however, before a rush to the doors gave token that the host was closing them for the night.
column3: He had not been thus long occupied, however, before a rush to the doors gave token that the host was closing them for the night.

column2: It was something even more intense than despair that I then observed upon the countenance of the singular being whom I had watched so pertinaciously.
column3: It was something even more intense than despair that I then observed upon the countenance of the singular being whom I had watched so pertinaciously.

column2: Yet he did not hesitate in his career, but, with a mad energy, retraced his steps at once, to the heart of the mighty London.
column3: Yet he did not hesitate in his career, but, with a mad energy, retraced his steps at once, to the heart of the mighty London.

column2: Long and swiftly he fled, while I followed him in the wildest amazement, resolute not to abandon a scrutiny in which I now felt an interest all-absorbing.
column3: Long and swiftly he fled, while I followed him in the wildest amazement, resolute not to abandon a scrutiny in which I now felt an interest all absorbing.

column2: The sun arose while we proceeded, and, when we had once again reached that most thronged mart of the populous town, the street of the D----- Hotel, it presented an appearance of human bustle and activity scarcely inferior to what I had seen on the evening before. And here, long, amid the momently increasing confusion, did I persist in my pursuit of the stranger.
column3: The sun arose while we proceeded, and, when we had once again reached that most thronged mart of the populous town, the street of the D----- Hotel, it presented an appearance of human bustle and activity scarcely inferior to what I had seen on the evening before. And here, long, amid the momently increasing confusion, did I persist in my pursuit of the stranger.

column2: But, as usual, he walked to and fro, and during the day did not pass from out the turmoil of that street.
column3: But, as usual, he walked to and fro, and during the day did not pass from out the turmoil of that street.

column2: And, as the shades of the second evening came on, I grew wearied unto death, and, stopping fully in front of the wanderer, gazed at him steadfastly in the face.
column3: And, as the shades of the second evening came on, I grew wearied unto death, and, stopping fully in front of the wanderer, gazed at him steadfastly in the face.

column2: He noticed me not, but resumed his solemn walk, while I, ceasing to follow, remained absorbed in contemplation.
column3: He noticed me not, but resumed his solemn walk, while I, ceasing to follow, remained absorbed in contemplation.

column2: This old man, I said at length, "is the type and the genius of deep crime.
column3: This old man, I said at length, "is the type and the genius of deep crime.

column2: He refuses to be alone.
column3: He refuses to be alone.

column2: [page 228:] He is the man of the crowd.
column3: [page two hundred twenty eight:] He is the man of the crowd.

column2: It will be in vain to follow; for I shall learn no more of him, nor of his deeds.
column3: It will be in vain to follow; for I shall learn no more of him, nor of his deeds.

column2: The worst heart of the world is a grosser book than the 'Hortulus Animae,' {*1} and perhaps it is but one of the great mercies of God that 'er lasst sich nicht lesen.'"
column3: The worst heart of the world is a grosser book than the 'Hortulus Animae,' {asterisk one} and perhaps it is but one of the great mercies of God that 'er lasst sich nicht lesen.'"
